newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crudes struggle, U.S. arbitrage narrows.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crudes struggle, U.S. arbitrage narrows.

text.p: North Sea spot crude premiums edged lower on Wednesday as sellers struggled to place prompt barrels and the U.S. arbitrage narrowed further, traders said.
Most North Sea grades with prompt loading dates were suffering from a lack of local refinery demand and the absence of a workable arbitrage to the U.S.
"It seems to have stalled a bit but maybe the buyers will start to come out at the lower numbers," said a North Sea seller.
Statfjord, Oseberg and Gullfaks were the weakest but Ekofisk was gaining some support from talk of production problems.
Some loadings of Ekofisk crude in September have been delayed by a day due to lower than expected production.
"The Ekofisk programme has been deferred by a day for cargoes loading September 10-17," said a trader familiar with the system's operations.
A cargo loading Sept 23 fetched Dated Brent +35 cents a barrel, which traders described as a strong premium compared to other grades.
Prompt Oseberg traded at Dated Brent +15 cents, with late pricing, while Statfjord moved at around Dated Brent +15/+18 cents, traders said.
Oct Brent paper was nearly 50 cents stronger at $20.50 a barrel on Wednesday afternoon, pulled higher by strong products markets in the United States.
Paper spreads were steady from early levels with Sept/Oct at +43/+46 cents, but Dated Brent was mired around 25/30 cents below September with two or three cargoes available, traders said.
CFDs were marked slightly softer to reflect the bearish spot market sentiment, dealers said.
